PLA and PLGA microspheres of ␤-galactosidase: Effect of
formulation factors on protein antigenicity and immunogenicity
N. Stivaktakis, 1 K. Nikou, 1,2 Z. Panagi, 1 A. Beletsi, 1 L. Leondiadis, 2 K. Avgoustakis 1
1 Laboratory of Pharmaceutical Technology, Department of Pharmacy, University of Patras,
Rion 26500, Greece
2 Laboratory of Immunepeptide Chemistry, NCSR "Demokritos," Aghia Paraskevi Attikis,
Athens 153 10, Greece
Received 26 January 2004; revised 19 March 2004; accepted 19 March 2004
Published online 20 May 2004
in Wiley InterScience
(www.interscience.wiley.com). DOI: 10.1002/jbm.a.30085
Abstract:
The entrapment of ␤-galactosidase (Escherichia
coli) in PLA and PLGA microspheres using a double emul-
sion technique resulted to significant reduction of protein
antigenicity. The extent of antigenicity loss depended on the
conditions of microsphere preparation. Most of antigenicity
loss occurred on the first emulsification step. Only the effects
of microsphere preparation factors having an important in-
fluence on protein antigenicity, such as the type of organic
phase (polymer solvent) and homogenization, could be pre-
dicted (on a qualitative basis) by antigenicity data obtained
after the first emulsification step. The type of polymer and
polymer solvent used to prepare the microspheres affected
␤-galactosidase immunogenicity. The PLA microspheres
prepared using ethyl acetate was the most immunogenic
microsphere formulation, eliciting similar total antibody re-
sponses as the alum formulation of ␤-gal. This formulation
was the only microsphere formulation that induced an
IgG1/IgG2a ratio lower than 1, indicating an immune re-
sponse biased towards a Th 1 type. The results obtained
indicate that large protein molecules with complex tertiary
structure such as ␤-galactosidase can be entrapped in PLA
and PLGA microspheres with retention of protein immuno-
genic potential, providing that appropriate conditions of
microsphere preparation are applied, and that the formula-
tion of microspheres might influence the Th 1 /Th 2 type of
immune response against the encapsulated antigen.
